item.title: Experience
item.description:
International Summer School on Low-Carbon Innovation – Shanghai Jiao Tong University
Led the coordination and facilitation of the 2025 Sino-British International Low Carbon College Summer School at Shanghai Jiao Tong University, bringing together 30 outstanding students from 15 countries. The program featured interdisciplinary workshops, cutting-edge lectures, corporate visits, and cultural exchange activities focused on carbon neutrality and sustainable development. Participants developed practical solutions for low-carbon campus design, fostering cross-cultural collaboration, innovation, and a shared commitment to global climate action.
Sustainable Development International Collaboration
View Details
AI Photonics International Summer School – Beihang University
Participated in the 2025 AI Photonics International Summer School at Beihang University, joining nearly 100 students and faculty from 13 countries. The program combined expert lectures, hands-on workshops with advanced optical devices, and interdisciplinary group projects, exploring AI applications in photonics, quantum optics, and intelligent communications. Through practical experiments, academic presentations, and cultural exchange, I enhanced my innovation, teamwork, and global collaboration skills while gaining exposure to cutting-edge research and technologies.
AI Photonics Cross Disciplinary Innovation
View Details
Executive Short Course on Space Project Management – RCSSTEAP & UNOOSA
Participated in the Executive Short Course on Space Project Management (Nov 2025) at Beihang University’s Hangzhou International Campus, organized by RCSSTEAP and UNOOSA. The five-day program covered the full lifecycle of space projects, including planning, budgeting, systems engineering, risk management, and AI applications in space missions. Through lectures, case studies, and hands-on exercises, I gained practical experience in project management while collaborating with international participants, enhancing cross-cultural teamwork, and understanding best practices for global space projects and satellite mission implementation.
Space Project Management International Collaboration
View Details
GEO Symposium & ODOK Workshop 2024 – Hangzhou, China
Volunteered at the 2024 GEO Symposium and Open Data & Open Knowledge (ODOK) Workshop in Hangzhou, assisting with event organization, translation, and coordination. Supported plenary and parallel sessions, live demonstrations, and collaborative workshops, helping facilitate smooth communication and engagement among international participants. This experience enhanced my cross-cultural teamwork, event management skills, and understanding of global Earth observation initiatives.
Earth Observation International Collaboration
View Details
Belt and Road Beidou Navigation Training – Beijing, China
Participated in the Belt and Road International Talent Training Program on Aerospace and the Beidou Navigation System in Beijing, organized by RCSSTEAP and partner institutions. The program combined theoretical lectures and hands-on practical sessions, covering Beidou navigation principles, coordinate systems, time services, and receiver performance testing. Gained direct experience with high-precision positioning, data analysis, and real-world aerospace applications during a visit to the Beijing Research Institute of Telemetry. This training enhanced my technical expertise in satellite navigation and fostered international collaboration in aerospace technology.
Beidou Navigation Aerospace Training
View Details
Advanced GNSS RTK UAV Navigation Study – United Nations/Indonesia Workshop
Presented a research project at the United Nations/Indonesia Workshop on GNSS applications, focusing on Real-Time Kinematic (RTK) positioning across multi-platform UAVs using the MAVLink protocol. Conducted experiments on Holybro X500 and DJI Matrice 350 UAVs, evaluating centimeter-level positioning accuracy, low-latency telemetry exchange, and system reliability under diverse environmental conditions. The study demonstrated a cost-effective RTK configuration applicable for precision aerial operations in agriculture, infrastructure inspection, environmental mapping, and disaster response, highlighting potential for international cooperation and broader GNSS adoption.
GNSSRTK UAV Navigation
View Details

item.title: Projects
item.description:
Unveiling Spatial Patterns of Aircraft Occurrences in Brazil Through Clustering and Statistical Analysis
I was part of this research project that investigates aircraft incidents in Brazil using statistical analysis and machine learning techniques to uncover spatial patterns and contributing risk factors in aviation safety. Our work focused heavily on cleaning and correcting inconsistent geographic and aircraft data from the national aviation database maintained by CENIPA, then applying clustering methods such as K-Means, Agglomerative clustering, and density-based approaches alongside statistical tests like chi-square and logistic regression. The analysis revealed clear regional patterns tied to air-traffic infrastructure and showed significant relationships between incident characteristics and their geographic distribution, demonstrating how data-driven methods can support better risk assessment and safety planning in Brazil’s aviation sector.
ML - Clustering
View Paper (Will be available soon...)
Custom-Built Autonomous Drone Platform Using Holybro X500 Frame
This project involved building and configuring a fully functional drone based on the X500 frame from Holybro, integrating flight control hardware, sensors, and onboard computing into a stable aerial platform. The work covered mechanical assembly, flight controller configuration, power distribution, firmware setup, and calibration, followed by test flights to validate stability and responsiveness. The project demonstrates hands-on experience with UAV hardware integration, embedded systems, and real-world debugging, forming a foundation for future work in autonomous navigation, computer vision, or aerial robotics applications.
Holybro-X500
AI-Assisted Collision Avoidance System
This project presents a self-developed AI-assisted collision avoidance system that detects obstacles in real time using depth sensing and computer vision. It uses an Intel RealSense D435i camera to capture 3D spatial data and combines depth analysis with a CNN-based model to improve detection reliability, generating color-coded safety alerts based on distance. Built primarily in Python with libraries such as OpenCV and TensorFlow, the system maintains real-time performance near 30 FPS while supporting modular components, dataset generation, and deployment on lightweight hardware including Raspberry Pi. AI development tools like GitHub Copilot and ChatGPT were used to accelerate experimentation, optimization, and debugging, illustrating how modern AI-assisted workflows can enable efficient development of practical real-time vision systems.
Collision Avoidance
View Details
Real-Time Kinematic Performance Evaluation of Mosaic-H GNSS Receiver on UAV Platforms Under Diverse Environmental Conditions
This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of the Mosaic-H GNSS receiver's Real-Time Kinematic (RTK) performance when integrated with UAV platforms across diverse environments—including open-sky, urban canyon, and forested areas. Through systematic testing, the study achieved an 88.2% RTK fixed solution rate overall, with horizontal accuracy averaging 3.1 cm in optimal conditions. Key findings established critical operational thresholds: maintaining >10 m clearance from buildings to prevent multipath degradation, canopy coverage above 70% triggering float solutions, and speeds exceeding 8 m/s challenging phase tracking. The research introduced a novel Multipath Impact Score (MP Score) correlating environmental factors with positioning quality (R² = 0.87), and demonstrated that operating at altitudes of 20–25 m significantly improves fix stability and correction density. These results provide empirical benchmarks and operational guidelines for reliable centimeter-level UAV navigation in complex environments, with direct applications to precision agriculture, infrastructure inspection, and autonomous surveying.
RTK GNSS UAV Navigation
View Paper

For this assignment, I created a static personal blog website using Hugo, a fast and flexible static site generator. I chose the Hugo Profile theme for its modern design and professional appearance that aligns with my goal of showcasing my work as a web developer.

item.title: Assignment 1
item.description:
Matrix Multiplication Project Report

Student Name: ODAI OTHMAN

Student ID: LS2425241

Submission Date: May 3. 2025

System Configuration

Category Output
CPU Model 11th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-11800H @ 2.30GHz
Memory Size 7.0 GiB
Operating System Linux MUP 5.15.167.4-microsoft-standard-WSL2 #1 SMP Tue Nov 5 00:21:55 UTC 2024 x86_64 GNU/Linux
Compiler Version gcc (Debian 12.2.0-14) 12.2.0
Python Version Python 3.9.12

Implementation Details

C Language Implementation

Source Code:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

#define SIZE 3  // Matrix size (3x3)

void print_matrix(int matrix[SIZE][SIZE]) {
    for (int i = 0; i < SIZE; i++) {
        for (int j = 0; j < SIZE; j++) {
            printf("%d\t", matrix[i][j]);
        }
        printf("\n");
    }
}

void multiply_matrices(int A[SIZE][SIZE], int B[SIZE][SIZE], int result[SIZE][SIZE]) {
    for (int i = 0; i < SIZE; i++) {
        for (int j = 0; j < SIZE; j++) {
            result[i][j] = 0;
            for (int k = 0; k < SIZE; k++) {
                result[i][j] += A[i][k] * B[k][j];
            }
        }
    }
}

int main() {
    int matrixA[SIZE][SIZE] = {{1, 2, 3}, {4, 5, 6}, {7, 8, 9}};
    int matrixB[SIZE][SIZE] = {{9, 8, 7}, {6, 5, 4}, {3, 2, 1}};
    int result[SIZE][SIZE];

    multiply_matrices(matrixA, matrixB, result);

    printf("Matrix A:\n");
    print_matrix(matrixA);
    printf("\nMatrix B:\n");
    print_matrix(matrixB);
    printf("\nResult (A × B):\n");
    print_matrix(result);

    return 0;
}

Sample Output:
